newsitem.title: DUBAI: Stricter Saudi regulations may hit tax holidays.
newsitem.headline: Stricter Saudi regulations may hit tax holidays.

text.p: Stricter enforcement of Saudi Commerce Ministry regulations may have adverse tax consequences for limited liability companies (LLC) with foreign partners, a legal journal said.

Legal News of the Gulf, published by the Riyadh-based Hasan al-Mulla Lawyers and Legal Consultants, said the ministry is sticking to its requirement that the LLC's articles of association must first be published in the official gazette before the LLC's annual commercial registration.
Only contracts signed after the registration are eligible for tax holidays, the journal obtained on Sunday said.

It said that as publication of articles often took several months, the ministry had in the past registered a company without it. It simply required a copy confirming the company's submission of its articles to the gazette.
"Now the Ministry of Commerce sticks to the rules and requests a proof that the summary of the Articles of Association was published before it registers the company," it said.

"This requirement may cause adverse tax consequences for foreign firms. A foreign company often decides to establish a joint venture only after a significant project in the kingdom had come to its attention," the journal said.
Saudi law gives LLCs with at least 25 percent Saudi shareholding tax holidays ranging from five to 10 years, depending on what sector they operate in.
